para: Pin internal boundary nodes. Internal boundaries lie between regions of different pixel categories in a µ.

Pinning internal boundaries is especially useful when cleaning up a &skel; that has been adapted to the material boundaries of a µ. (a) shows a &skel; with pinned internal boundary nodes. (b) shows the same &skel; after having been smoothed. The pinned nodes have not moved, although the targets parameter for was set to .

Note that &nodes; on internal boundaries in a &skel; do not necessarily lie exactly on the pixel boundaries in a µ. A &node; is considered to be on an internal boundary if it is part of two &elems; with different dominant pixels. (a) shows a detail from (a) where the pinned &nodes; are clearly not on the pixel boundaries. When the &elems; are colored according to their dominant pixels as in (b), it is clear that the pinned nodes are actually boundary nodes of the &skel;.
